1.brief: to be strong; causatively, to stregthen, i.e. (figuratively) to save (by flight)
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
Binjamin, youngest son of Jacob; also the tribe descended from him, and its territory
properly, the nearest part, i.e. the center, whether literal, figurative or adverbial (especially with preposition)
Jerushalaim or Jerushalem, the capital city of Palestine
to clatter, i.e. slap (the hands together), clang (an instrument); by analogy, to drive (a nail or tent-pin, a dart, etc.); by implication, to become bondsman by handclasping)
a cornet (as giving a clear sound) or curved horn
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
to lift, in a great variety of applications, literal and figurative, absolute and relative

properly, (abstractly) a raising (as of the hands in prayer), or rising (of flame); figuratively, an utterance; concretely, a beacon (as raised); a present (as taken), mess, or tribute; figuratively, a reproach (as a burden)
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
properly, to lean out (of a window), i.e. (by implication) peep or gaze (passively, be a spectacle)
properly, hidden, i.e. dark; used only of the north as aquarter (gloomy and unknown)
a fracture, figuratively, ruin; specifically, a solution (of a dream)
great (in any sense); hence, older; also insolent

to be dumb or silent; hence, to fail or perish; trans. to destroy
a daughter (used in the same wide sense as other terms of relationship, literally and figuratively)
Tsijon (as a permanent capital), a mountain of Jerusalem

to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
to tend a flock; i.e. pasture it; intransitively, to graze (literally or figuratively); generally to rule; by extension, to associate with (as a friend)

a tent (as clearly conspicuous from a distance)

to ascend, intransitively (be high) or actively (mount); used in a great variety of senses, primary and secondary, literal and figurative

to turn; by implication, to face, i.e. appear, look, etc.

to ascend, intransitively (be high) or actively (mount); used in a great variety of senses, primary and secondary, literal and figurative
properly, a twist (away of the light), i.e. night; figuratively, adversity
to decay, i.e. (causatively) ruin (literally or figuratively)

properly, like this, i.e. by implication, (of manner) thus (or so); also (of place) here (or hither); or (of time) now

Jerushalaim or Jerushalem, the capital city of Palestine

properly, united, i.e. sole; by implication, beloved; also lonely; (feminine) the life (as not to be replaced)
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
properly, to be burly, i.e. (figuratively) powerful (passively, impregnable); by implication, to ravage
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications

27.brief: to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
a fortification, castle, or fortified city; figuratively, a defender

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
to test (especially metals); generally and figuratively, to investigate
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb

28.brief: properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
to turn away, i.e. (morally) be refractory
to walk (in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively)
copper, hence, something made of that metal, i.e. coin, a fetter; figuratively, base (as compared with gold or silver)
iron (as cutting); by extension, an iron implement
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
to decay, i.e. (causatively) ruin (literally or figuratively)

29.brief: to glow, i.e. literally (to melt, burn, dry up) or figuratively (to show or incite passion)
evil (as destructive), literally (ruin) or morally (especially guile); figuratively idolatry (as false, subjective), uselessness (as deceptive, objective; also adverbially, in vain)
to fuse (metal), i.e. refine (literally or figuratively)
to fuse (metal), i.e. refine (literally or figuratively)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

30.brief: silver (from its pale color); by implication, money
to call out to (i.e. properly, address by name, but used in a wide variety of applications)
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
